intro: Villaresia paraguariensis var. intermedia, commonly known as the Amazonian guaraná, is a climbing shrub native to the Amazon rainforest. It belongs to the Sterculiaceae family and is characterized by its woody stems and large, heart-shaped leaves. The plant produces bright yellow flowers that are clustered in panicles, followed by elongated pods containing elliptical seeds. Its most notable feature is the presence of caffeine-rich seeds, which are used in traditional medicine and as a stimulant. The varietal form intermedia is distinguished by its intermediate characteristics between the typical species and other related varieties.
